questions.text: A 21-year-old girl presented to the surgeon, complaints of an incidentally detected small mass in the left breast. Physical examination revealed it is soft, non-tender and highly mobile. It is occasionally associated with pain during menstruation. The mammogram performed shows BIRADS 3 (benign lesion). Which of the following is the best, highly sensitive investigation that provides results within 2-3 days to confirm the nature of the mass?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

FNAC is the first-line, minimally invasive, day-care procedure for cytological assessment of breast lesions, yielding results within 2-3 days and with sensitivity > 90%.

It samples cellular material to differentiate benign from malignant processes without requiring anaesthesia or an operating theatre.

High negative predictive value and low complication rates make FNAC the recommended first-line diagnostic modality, guiding further management and the need for more invasive biopsies.

Explanation of Other Options:

Incisional biopsy (Option B): Invasive surgical procedure requiring anaesthesia and operating theatre, with longer processing time (3-5 days), reserved when FNAC is inconclusive.

Immunohistochemistry (Option C): Laboratory technique performed on tissue samples to characterise tumour markers; not used as an initial diagnostic test and requires prior tissue acquisition.

Excisional biopsy (Option D): Definitive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure involving complete surgical removal of the lesion; more invasive and time-consuming compared to FNAC, with results typically taking longer.

choices.text: Lesion is encapsulated and rubbery in consistency, grossly
The epithelium shows an intracanalicular and pericanalicular pattern
Stroma shows myxoid change and oedema
Glands are lined by a single layer of epithelium with nucleomegaly and prominent nucleoli

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient has undergone excision of a mass as it is gradually increasing in size, and USG examination shows BIRADS 2 (benign) nature on mammogram. But she underwent excision of the lesion, and the histopathological image is shown below. All of the below given statements below are true regarding the diagnosis, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

True fibroadenomas maintain a double-layered epithelial lining without nuclear atypia. A single epithelial layer with nucleomegaly and prominent nucleoli indicates atypia or malignancy

Fibroadenomas:

  • Fibroadenomas are benign, well-circumscribed, encapsulated, rubbery nodules that bulge above surrounding tissue and often contain slit-like spaces due to stromal proliferation. (Option A)
  • The delicate and often edematous myxoid stroma resembles normal intralobular stroma. (Option C)
  • The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern). (Option B)
  • In older women, the stroma typically becomes densely hyalinized, and the epithelium atrophic.
  • Fibroadenomas are associated with a slightly increased risk of carcinoma, a risk that may be higher if "complex" features are present (cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change).

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady patient presented with a breast lump in the upper quadrant, which has been slowly increasing in size for 6 months. Physical examination revealed it is a hard mass and fixed to the underlying structures. Axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Tru-Cut biopsy from the mass was performed, and histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common breast malignancy, defined by irregular, angulated glands infiltrating through fibrofatty tissue. This histologic pattern matches the scattered neoplastic glands seen on biopsy.

Glands are lined by a single layer of epithelium and show pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli.

The tumour elicits a dense desmoplastic reaction (fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition) that produces a firm, fixed mass clinically and a gritty cut surface grossly.

Malignant ductal cells show cytologic atypia with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures, confirming carcinoma and distinguishing it from benign lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Medullary carcinoma (Option B): Characterised by syncytial sheets of high-grade cells with a brisk lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and well-circumscribed, pushing borders, not the infiltrating angulated glands and desmoplastic stroma seen here.

Phyllodes tumour (Option C): Exhibits nodules of proliferating stroma covered by epithelium; distinguished from fibroadenoma by increased stromal cellularity, higher mitotic rate, nuclear pleomorphism, stromal overgrowth, and infiltrative borders-features absent in this sample.

Lobular carcinoma (Option D): Composed of dyscohesive cells that infiltrate in single-file or targetoid patterns due to E-cadherin loss, rather than forming cohesive glandular structures.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady patient presented with a breast lump in the upper quadrant, which has been slowly increasing in size for 6 months. Physical examination revealed that it is a hard mass and fixed to the underlying structures. Axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. MRM was performed, and a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, NOS was made, the image of which is shown below. The consultant requested grading using the standard histologic grading system. Which of the following components is not included in that grading?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard histologic grading system for breast carcinoma is the Nottingham (modified Bloom-Richardson) Histologic Score. Carcinomas are scored for tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic rate. It assigns a score of 1-3 for each of three parameters

Total score → Grade

  • 3-5: Grade I (well differentiated)
  • 6-7: Grade II (moderately differentiated)
  • 8-9: Grade III (poorly differentiated)

Although necrosis is frequently seen in high-grade carcinomas, it is not a parameter scored in the Nottingham system.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a 1 cm painless mass in the right breast, lower quadrant. Physical examination revealed a hard, non-tender and mobile lump. Ultrasound performed suggests neoplastic aetiology. Tru-Cut biopsy from the lesion was taken, and the histopathological examination was performed (image below). Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lobular carcinoma is defined by dyscohesive tumour cells infiltrating the stroma in single-file or targetoid patterns, reflecting loss of E-cadherin-mediated adhesion, as seen on biopsy.

The neoplastic cells are small, uniform, and lack tubule formation, lining the stroma individually rather than forming cohesive nests or duct-like structures.

Clinically, lobular carcinoma often presents subtly on imaging and may be multifocal or bilateral, making histologic recognition of its characteristic infiltration pattern essential.

They also have distinctive patterns of metastatic spread, often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, the leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis), the gastrointestinal tract, and the ovaries and uterus.

Males and females with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 are at increased risk for developing lobular carcinoma and have a greatly increased risk for signet ring carcinoma of the stomach

Explanation of Other Options:

Invasive ductal carcinoma (Option A): Forms cohesive, angulated glands with a desmoplastic stromal reaction, not the single-file infiltration of lobular carcinoma.

Medullary carcinoma (Option C): Composed of syncytial sheets of high-grade cells with a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and pushing borders, lacking single-cell cords.

Tubular carcinoma (Option D): Consists almost entirely of well-formed tubules with open lumens and bland cytology, without dyscohesive single-file cells.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female presented with a right breast lump detected for 3 months and was gradually increasing in size. Physical examination confirms a 1 cm nodule in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Tru-Cut biopsy was performed, and based on the histopathological findings, a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, NOS was made. Oncologist asks for IHC, the image of which is given below. IHC shows membrane positivity. Which marker is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Her2neu is a transmembrane tyrosine kinase receptor. IHC reveals a distinct circumferential (membrane) staining pattern when overexpressed in tumour cells.

Estrogen and progesterone receptors (ER/PR) are nuclear transcription factors, yielding nuclear staining, and Ki-67 is a nuclear proliferation marker - none produce membrane localisation.

Membrane positivity for HER2neu has direct therapeutic implications, as it identifies candidates for HER2-targeted therapies (e.g., trastuzumab).

Explanation of Other Options:

Estrogen receptor (Option A): A nuclear stain highlighting hormone-responsive tumour cells; not membrane localised.

Progesterone receptor (Option B): Also a nuclear stain; indicates hormone sensitivity but shows nuclear positivity only.

Ki67 (Option D): Labels proliferating nuclei; used to gauge growth fraction, with nuclear staining pattern.

choices.text: It shows sheets of tumour cells having uniform round to oval nuclei and inconspicuous nucleoli
Moderate to marked lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate within the tumour
It's present as pushing the border
It's included in the triple-negative breast carcinoma classification

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman in routine screening mammography was found to have a 2 cm circumscribed mass, without calcification, in her left breast. An excisional biopsy was performed, and based on histopathological findings diagnosis of medullary carcinoma was made. All of the below-mentioned statements are true regarding the medullary carcinoma, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medullary carcinoma is defined by syncytial sheets of large, pleomorphic cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, rather than uniform, bland nuclei.

  • These tumours often display abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and brisk mitotic activity, correlating with their high-grade appearance.
  • Over half of BRCA1-associated breast cancers display a medullary pattern, and although most sporadic medullary tumours lack BRCA1 mutations, BRCA1 promoter hypermethylation (leading to reduced expression) occurs in ~67% of cases.
  • Correct identification of nuclear pleomorphism is essential to distinguish medullary carcinoma from lower-grade or benign circumscribed lesions.
  • A dense lymphoid infiltrate is a hallmark of medullary carcinoma. (Option B)
  • These tumours characteristically have well-circumscribed, noninfiltrative (pushing) margins. (Option C)
  • Medullary carcinoma typically lacks ER, PR, and HER2 expression, placing it in the triple-negative category. (Option D)

questions.text: A 63-year-old female presents with an oozing, reddish patch on her left nipple, with occasional blood-stained discharge. The patient has a history of skin rashes and food allergies and believes this condition is due to an allergic reaction. Punch biopsy was performed and sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paget's disease of the breast is characterised by malignant epithelial (Paget) cells within the epidermis of the nipple-areolar complex, producing persistent eczematous changes and bloody discharge.

Histologically, Paget cells are large cells with pale or clear cytoplasm and atypical nuclei seen singly or in small clusters within the epidermis.

The clinical presentation - nipple crusting and oozing unresponsive to topical therapy, along with biopsy-confirmed Paget cells, is diagnostic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chronic dermatitis (Option A): Histology shows dense inflammatory cells in the dermis with or without fibrosis, but lacks intraepidermal Paget cells.

Intraductal papilloma (Option B): Presents clinically with blood-stained nipple discharge; histology reveals papillary fronds lined by epithelium with fibrovascular cores within dilated ducts, not epidermal involvement.

Phyllodes tumour (Option D): A fibroepithelial neoplasm of the breast parenchyma showing a hypercellular stroma with increased mitotic activity and leaf-like architecture, without involvement of the nipple epidermis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presented to the surgeon with a lump in the right breast for 2 months, as she is afraid it is cancer. After mammography was performed, which was suggestive of a benign lesion, she underwent excision of the lesion. Specimen sent for histopathological examination image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion demonstrates a biphasic, fibroepithelial architecture with hypercellular stroma forming leaf-like projections lined by epithelium, a defining feature of phyllodes tumour.

Unlike fibroadenoma, phyllodes tumour shows marked stromal overgrowth, increased mitotic activity (often >10 mitoses per 10 HPF), and stromal nuclear pleomorphism.

Infiltrative stromal margins and atypia correlate with potential for recurrence and malignancy, necessitating wider excision.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fibroadenoma (Option A): Displays a delicate, myxoid stroma and pericanalicular/intracanalicular epithelial patterns without significant stromal hypercellularity or mitotic activity.

Fibrocystic disease (Option B): Characterised by cystic dilation of ducts, apocrine metaplasia, and stromal fibrosis; histology reveals cysts lined by bland epithelium and fibrotic stroma without leaf-like architecture.

Invasive ductal carcinoma (Option C): Shows angulated malignant glands within a desmoplastic stroma and cytologic atypia, lacking the biphasic stromal-epithelial pattern.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented with a painless left-sided breast lump for the last 2 months. Local examination revealed a soft, mobile, nontender mass. Excision biopsy was done, and the histopathological image is as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Painless left-sided breast lump, which is a soft, mobile, nontender mass, looks like a benign lesion. The histopathology shows proliferation of pinkish stroma and ducts, which have become distorted. This is suggestive of fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenomas:

  • Fibroadenomas are benign, well-circumscribed, encapsulated, rubbery nodules that bulge above surrounding tissue and often contain slit-like spaces due to stromal proliferation.
  • The delicate and often myxoid stroma resembles normal intralobular stroma. The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern).
  • In older women, the stroma typically becomes densely hyalinized, and the epithelium atrophic.
  • Fibroadenomas are associated with a slightly increased risk of carcinoma, a risk that may be higher if "complex" features are present (cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change).

Explanation of Other Options:

Phyllodes tumour (Option A): A fibroepithelial neoplasm with hypercellular stroma forming leaf-like projections, increased mitotic figures, and infiltrative margins-features absent here.

Fibrocystic disease (Option B): Characterised by cystic dilation of ducts, apocrine metaplasia, and stromal fibrosis; lacks the well-formed stroma-epithelium compression seen in fibroadenoma.

Ductal carcinoma in situ (Option D): Exhibits malignant epithelial cells confined within ducts, often with comedo necrosis, and no stromal overgrowth or ductal compression by benign stroma.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma on core biopsy. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) for HER2 was performed, and the pathologist requested fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) to confirm gene amplification. For which HER2 IHC score is reflex FISH testing recommended?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is based on the ASCO/CAP criteria (American Society of Clinical Oncology/College of American Pathologists) for HER2 testing in breast cancer, which standardise IHC scoring and reflex FISH recommendations.

An Immunohistochemistry (IHC) score of 2+ yields an equivocal membrane staining pattern - weak to moderate complete circumferential staining in >10% of tumour cells or strong staining in ≤10%, and thus requires FISH to determine true HER2 gene amplification.

By contrast, IHC 3+ demonstrates unequivocal strong, uniform membrane staining in >10% of tumour cells (true positive), and IHC 1+ shows faint or incomplete staining (negative); neither necessitates further testing.

Reflex FISH for 2+ cases ensures accurate HER2 classification and appropriate selection of HER2-targeted therapies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the clinic with a 4 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant. Biopsy bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma. Which of the following is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Colloid (mucinous) carcinoma is characterised by clusters of uniform epithelial cells floating in large pools of extracellular mucin, accounting for the bland nuclear features amidst the mucinous stroma.

Colloid Carcinoma

  • Colloid carcinoma is seen in about 2% cases, occurs more frequently in older women and is slow-growing.
  • Colloid carcinoma has a better prognosis than the usual infiltrating duct carcinoma.
  • Grossly, the tumour is usually a soft and gelatinous mass with well-demarcated borders.
  • Colloid carcinoma containsa large amount of extracellular epithelial mucin and acini filled with mucin. Cuboidal to tall columnar tumour cells, some showing mucus vacuolation, are seen floating in large lakes of mucin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Comedo carcinoma (Option B): A form of ductal carcinoma in situ featuring malignant ductal cells filling ducts with central "comedo" necrosis, but lacks extracellular mucin pools.

Papillary carcinoma (Option C): Forms papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores within ducts, not pools of extracellular mucin.

Medullary carcinoma (Option D): Composed of syncytial sheets of pleomorphic cells with a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and pushing borders, without mucin production.

questions.text: Van Nuys prognostic indicator for DCIS does not include which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) classifies patients with DCIS to guide decisions on the best treatment option. The index uses patient age, tumour size, tumour growth patterns (histological grade) and the amount of healthy tissue surrounding the tumour after removal (resection margin width) to predict the risk of cancer returning.

"Type of DCIS" is not a VNPI parameter.


*RFS - recurrence-free survival

**BCSS - breast cancer-specific survival after WLE + RT, mastectomy was excluded.

choices.text: Good prognosis with HRT and trastuzumab
Good prognosis, trastuzumab therapy can be given
Good prognosis, trastuzumab therapy should not be given

questions.text: The pictures below show a breast biopsy specimen on which immunohistochemical staining for ER, PR and HER2 neu has been done. Which of the following is true about the prognosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given images show the breast tissue negatively stained for all three, i.e., ER, PR and HER2neu.
  • This profile (ER- /PR- /HER2-) defines triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), which accounts for ~10-15% of invasive carcinomas and is typically high grade and aggressive with a poor prognosis.
  • TNBC frequently aligns with the basal-like molecular subtype, characterised by CK5/6 and/or EGFR positivity, a high incidence of BRCA1 germline mutations, a tendency for early visceral metastases, and peak recurrence risk within the first 3-5 years after diagnosis.
  • The absence of hormone receptors and HER2 overexpression eliminates the use of endocrine therapies or HER2-targeted agents (trastuzumab).
  • Management, therefore, relies on multi-agent cytotoxic chemotherapy, with PARP inhibitors (in BRCA1/2-mutated cases) and immune checkpoint inhibitors emerging as promising options.
  • Overall, TNBC carries significantly lower disease-free and overall survival rates compared to other molecular subtypes of breast cancer.

Key Takeaways:

  • Triple-negative breast cancers are ER- /PR- /HER2-, high grade, often BRCA1-associated, and have a poor prognosis due to a lack of targeted therapies.
  • Treatment is primarily chemotherapy, with investigational use of PARP inhibitors in BRCA-mutated patients and immunotherapies.
